Aconia Review: The Cyber Assassin of the Super Elemental Family - Empires & Puzzles

Aconia brings a cyberpunk edge and a sadistic choice to the battlefield: keep her Dagger Fiend and suffer massive damage, or heal it and bleed out. Our review breaks down why this fast mana assassin is still a threat to Holy teams despite her aging stats.
Aconia: The Blade of the Void
Aconia, The Blade of the Void: Bleed, Fiends, and Cybernetic Precision
Aconia is a 5-star Legendary Dark hero from the

family, released back in May 2023. In an era of high fantasy, dragons, and goblins, Aconia burst onto the scene with a refreshing cyberpunk aesthetic and a kit designed to punish Holy enemies with ruthless efficiency.

mana Fiend Summoner who presents opponents with a sadistic "Sophie's Choice": suffer massive damage every turn from her Dagger Fiend, or heal it away and immediately take a burst of Bleed damage. While she lacks a costume, her base mechanics remain unique enough to warrant a look, even if her stats have started to gather a bit of dust.

Aconia’s design is a standout departure from the standard E&P fare. She sports a futuristic, cyber-rogue look with glowing neon purple accents, a digital visor, and a plasma-edged dagger that looks like it could slice through a firewall as easily as plate armor. The color palette is dominated by deep violets and electric pinks, perfectly signaling her Dark element and "Super Elemental" origin. It’s sleek, modern, and honestly, she looks like she’d be more at home hacking a mega-corporation in
Aconia’s stats were solid for 2023, but in the harsh light of late 2025, they are undeniably outdated.
While respectable, modern attackers boast base attack stats well over 1300.

These are her biggest weak points. Modern tanks and supports sit at 1300+ Defense and 2400+ Health. Aconia is fragile by today's standards and absolutely requires Limit Breaking (and likely double Limit Breaking) to survive a single hit from a modern sniper.
Aconia’s special skill is a masterclass in "damage over time" pressure.
She summons a Fiend for the target
all Holy enemies. This makes her a sniper against most teams, but a multi-target devastator against Holy-heavy formations.
. This is one of the highest Fiend damage multipliers in the game. It’s not a tickle; it’s a stab wound.
If the enemy heals enough (20% max HP) to remove the Fiend, they are slapped with

This skill creates a lose-lose scenario. If you ignore the Fiend, it eats your health rapidly. If you heal it, you trigger the bleed. However, this mechanic has a notable flaw (discussed in "Counters") involving the order of operations for cleansing healers.
Fast (7 tiles). With a lvl 29 Magic/Styx troop or minimal mana bonuses, she can fire in 6 tiles, making her extremely speedy.
With an LB2 Attack of ~1074 + Emblems/Troops bringing her to ~1400 Attack:
(before defense reduction). In practice, this hits for roughly 300-400 damage
over 3 turns (270 per turn). This ignores defense, which is excellent against high-defense modern tanks.
If a Fiend hits 3 times (~1000 dmg) and is then removed (810 bleed), a single cast can deal ~1800+ damage to a target over time without them ever being directly "hit."
Family Bonus, Passives, Aether Power & Unique Abilities

The Super Elemental family bonus generates Power Gems. While 20 damage per gem is negligible, the board control aspect shouldn't be ignored. Flooding the board with these gems can occasionally disrupt enemy tile play or deal chip damage that finishes off a low-HP enemy.
+100% additional elemental damage against Holy. This means her tiles hit like trucks against Yellow heroes.
-10% damage from Holy. A nice survival boost, but given her low base stats, it doesn't make her a tank.

is somewhat ironic for a Fiend summoner. It prevents her from receiving Fiends for the first 6 turns. This is incredibly useful in today's meta, protecting her from the likes of heavy Fiend spammers, ensuring she doesn't get bogged down and can keep firing.
Upon release, Aconia was feared for her high Fiend damage. She was a premier "Holy Killer" designed to break the dominance of yellow tanks.
Her stats have fallen behind significantly. She is no longer a viable defensive option. However, her
(250% scaling with Attack) keeps her relevant on offense.
She is still a weapon against Holy teams, especially in wars. If you see a team with 2+ Holy heroes, Aconia becomes a top-tier pick. In neutral matchups, there are better, harder-hitting options.
Aconia is a damage dealer, pure and simple. Her Fiend damage scales directly with her Attack stat. Survival is secondary; if she isn't killing things, she's useless.
Maximizes the 250% per turn Fiend damage. Increases tile damage (enhanced by her passive).
is the only logical choice. You are bringing her to bleed the enemy dry, not to tank hits.
Targets all Holy enemies and deals double tile damage to them.
250% damage per turn is massive and forces a reaction from the defense.
Can often fire before the enemy healer is ready, planting the "seed" of damage early.
810 damage ignores the absurd defense stats of modern heroes.
(like Rigard, Vivica, or Ariel) will remove the Fiend (triggering the bleed) and then
in the same action. This completely neutralizes her secondary damage.
She deals no immediate direct damage. If you need to kill an enemy
to stop them from firing, Aconia cannot help you.
Specifically against teams running Yellow tanks or double Yellow formations.
In Bloody Battle, healing is disabled. This means enemies generally
remove the Fiend, so they are stuck taking 250% damage every single turn until they die.
Her passive (+100% elemental damage) makes her tile damage incredible against Holy Titans.
. Darkfeather boosts the tile damage further, while Aconia punishes the Yellow heroes.
. Use heroes that block buffs or healing to ensure the Fiend stays on the target, milking that 250% damage for as long as possible.
. Rigard heals (removing the Fiend) and then Cleanses (removing the Bleed). He turns Aconia’s lethal trap into a minor inconvenience.
Do not pair her with heroes who block healing (like Pereshet)
you want the Bleed damage to trigger. However, keeping the Fiend on (for the 250% damage) is usually better than the Bleed, so anti-heal is actually a fine synergy.

If you pulled Aconia early, she is a fantastic sniper-esque hero. Her Fast mana makes her easy to use. Focus on targeting the enemy healer or the biggest threat. Don't worry about the complex mechanics; just know that once she hits someone, they are on a clock.
Aconia is a luxury toy for your deep war bench. She is not a primary ascension candidate over modern monsters like the Astral Demons or Constructs. However, she retains immense value in
tournaments. If you compete at a high level there, she is worth taking to 3/70 or 4/80, but think twice before committing Alpha Aethers unless you really need the help against Yellow Titans.
The community's reaction to Aconia was a mix of awe and skepticism.
“Interesting sniper giving you a sadistic choice. Either you keep the fiend... or you remove it and take 810 bleed damage.”
— This perfectly captures her design philosophy.
“Rigard renders Aconia’s fiends useless because he will heal first then cleanse.”
— Players quickly identified her Achilles' heel.
“In Bloody Battle, she is a goddess.”
— A sentiment that has held true years later.

Aconia is a hero who aged gracefully in niche roles while falling behind in the main meta. She is no longer the terrifying presence she was in mid-2023, but she remains a sharp, poisoned thorn in the side of any Holy-heavy team. She brings a unique flavor of "damned if you do, damned if you don't" gameplay that makes her incredibly fun to use on offense, even if she requires a bit of protection to survive the modern battlefield.
A specialized assassin. Keep her for Yellow Titans and Bloody Battle tournaments, but don't expect her to hold the line on defense.
At the time of this review, Aconia does not have a costume. If one is released, it will likely address her stats and potentially fix the "Heal then Cleanse" vulnerability.
